items.title: Testing Your App
items.body:
I think that Chap 4: "Testing your App" is misleading.  It does kinda work but cannot be used for real testing of the app.
deviceReady event does not get called for instance.  so code waiting to execute will not trigger.
I would like to see Testing your App with XCode/Safari.
How do you force an ionic build ios?
How do you run and see logging messages?
For some strange reason, I need to hit the run button twice to force the App to come up and trigger the deviceReady event.
ionic build ios also keeps adding the some facebook info to my app plist over and over again... How do you prevent that?
Just some ideas.
Thanks for great framework.
Pat.

items.title: Guide - iOS mobile testing
items.body:
http://ionicframework.com/docs/guide/testing.html
It says:
"You can also test the app directly in a mobile browser. For OS X users, Safari on OS X can directly debug websites and simulator applications. First you have to enable the remote web inspector on both the device and Safari on desktop. To do this with iOS 7 and OS X Mavericks, enable the Web Inspector option in the iOS Settings -> Safari -> Advanced section, and also enable the Developer Menu in the Advanced section of the Safari OS X settings."

It also works on my iOS 6 device and it works on installed Ionic apps (not just using the Safari browser in iOS). I didn't know about this feature it is VERY useful.

jacboy

items.title: Tiny typo in Guide / Testing your App
items.body: In the third code example **cordova** is falsely spelled "corodva"

items.title: Guide - desktop browser testing....
items.body:
http://ionicframework.com/docs/guide/testing.html
Says:

"......it's very easy to test in the desktop browser. The easiest thing is to cd into the www folder, and run

$ python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000
Substitute SimpleHTTPServer with http.server if your Python version is 3.x (run python --version to check)."

I think doing the following is perhaps the "easiest thing": (no need for Python)

http-server ./

Then in a browser go to http://localhost:8080 (or whatever the command line tool said is the port number - it might be 8083, etc) (to specify a port use -p then the port number)

I think to install it use

npm install -g http-server

(g is for "global" I think)

If there are error messages I think you can use sudo npm install -g http-server

items.title: Added tutorial for Protractor testing on the browser and with Ripple.
items.body:
I am new to nanoc, and I didn't see any unit tests or e2e tests. If there is some thing broken or some way to test, feel free to reject and let me know what I need to fix. 

I recently wrote my e2e tests and decided to make it work with ripple, there were a few hurdles and I thought other people might benefit from my trial and error. Then I went kind overboard and decided to just write an intro to protractor while I was at it. 


It was suggested that I contribute it to learn-ionic here: https://github.com/driftyco/ionic/issues/1642#issuecomment-46443335
Let me know what you think, and if you want me to rewrite anything before you would want to put it up.

items.title: black background on Safari desktop browser
items.body:
Everything else about the app looks fine in the Safari desktop browser except the background stays black. There doesn't seem to be a developer console to check for errors.

BTW though Ionic is for mobile devices I prefer them to also work on desktop browsers for testing purposes.

items.title: Please use meta viewport on Codepen demos
items.body:
In the HTML config we have an option "Stuff for < head>" use copy and paste this snippet there, using this meta I'll be able to open the full page on my mobile browser and test the demos

[h5bp/index.html#L11](https://github.com/h5bp/html5-boilerplate/blob/v4.2.0/index.html#L11)
```html
<meta name="viewport" content="width=device-width">
```

items.title: display/interaction problems in desktop firefox
items.body:
The background photos of the app display but the main and bottom pages are visible at the same time. 
![screen shot 2014-04-01 at 2 33 19 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/5137426/2575636/5b781b98-b957-11e3-8d25-c26faf4b8a9a.png)

The top-right gear works - without any transition animations. The other parts of the interface don't react to clicks or drags.

BTW though Ionic is for mobile devices I prefer them to also work on desktop browsers for testing purposes.

items.title: ngDemo is a Phonegap-build ready demo that exercises most of the existin...
items.body:
...g ngCordova plugins.  ngCordova lowers the bar for entry for Ionic/Angular users who may not yet have used a plugin.  This simple demo uses code from the ngCordova doc page and some additional sugar and window-dressing for smoke-testing use of new and existing ngCordova-defined plugins.  Currently, geolocation (works in browser, not in emulator or handset) and network do not work (pulling master keeps reverting the 'networkSate' error).  Also the Phonegap build config is Android only as I don't have an Apple app key.

![screen shot 2014-06-16 at 7 41 49 pm](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/219851/3294787/3f5cf8da-f5b0-11e3-8391-1acae6a41b69.png)

items.title: Request: Update starter projects
items.body:
Originally reported here: https://github.com/driftyco/ionic-starter-maps/issues/1

but I'm extending it to the general case here. What would be really cool is if the starter projects also followed the [yeoman generator-angular](https://github.com/yeoman/generator-angular) structure so that they could be used with the community generators ([original](https://github.com/diegonetto/generator-ionic), [my fork](https://github.com/JaKXz/generator-ionic), etc) but I understand if that's asking too much.

items.title: ion-tabs have issues on Samsung Galaxy Note 3 in beta5b
items.body:
When clicking a tab the icon highlights, but no action is performed. On subsequent touches it's possible to get tabs to perform action, but it's not predictable.

Problem exists on both starter app and custom build app.

To reproduce:

```
$ ionic start tabbed-project
```

Problem device info:
Samsung Galaxy Note 3
Android 4.4.2

Successfully works on:
Samsung Galaxy S5
Android 4.4.2

items.title: Disable Back button anim. for certain transitions
items.body:
The Ion Nav Back Button is designed to be shown and hidden using the add/remove class animation, to ensure an iOS 7 style transition when going forward/back through a navigation structure (e.g. overview page > detail page.)

This transition works fine, except when transitioning from one view (e.g. detail page) to another view (e.g. a different tab page) where the back button should be hidden. This causes the 'Back' button to be animated out of existence, when in fact it should be immediately removed.

E.g. In the Ionic Default Tab app, open 'Friends > Scruff McGruff', and then tab to 'Account'. You will notice a small delay before the 'Back' button is hidden, which is (noticeably) at a different time to when the Title is updated to 'Account' - both the title and the Back button should be updated/removed at the same time.

Ionic's ionNavBackButton directive should take account of the 'shouldAnimate' bool, so that the animation is not used when an immediate transition is required.

This pull request is an example of a potential fix to demonstrate how the back button transition animation should be disabled in certain circumstances.

items.title: [FEATURE] Swipe-To-Go-Back, iOS7-Style / Interactive View Transitions
items.body:
The new iOS7 navigation paradigm requires that users can always swipe to navigate backwards - in UIKit, this feature is called "Interactive Transitions".

This has been _excellently_ implemented in - only a few days old - "Framework 7" by the iDangerous guys:

Demo (Swipe from the left Screen Border):
http://www.idangero.us/framework7/#.UxRzo_RdXQw

Source:
https://github.com/nolimits4web/Framework7/blob/master/src/js/views.js

This would be the last gap to close to make Ionic non distinguishable from native on newer iOS7 based devices. :-) Please integrate it to the the Ionic framework.

items.title: Flags are not passed to cordova
[feature request] Horizontal bouncy scrolling in android
items.body:
After a bit of testing, I've come to the conclusion that in Android (tested on 4.3 + 4.4), Ionic is capable of 'bouncy' scrolling vertically, but not horizontally. I see from the documentation, that the ion-content directive has a "has-bouncing" property, though the directive itself is not capable of horizontal scrolling (atleast using the "ionic scroll method").

Interestingly enough, the ion-scroll directive seems to support horizontal scrolling, though it does not have a setting relating to "has-bouncing", thus on android, does not do that nice bouncy scrolling effect while scrolling the x axis. sadface!

I've posted this to the forums, and Ionic team member (Calendee), told me to create a feature request, so here it is ... :)

Forum thread: http://forum.ionicframework.com/t/horizontal-bouncy-scrolling-in-android/3612
Demo codepen: http://codepen.io/calendee/pen/HIuft

items.title: Delays on changing state of app
items.body:
Hi Ionic! I'm testing this framework on simulator, chrome emulation mode and iOS7 device (last iPad mini and iPhone 5) and noticed some delays during transitions between states. When I'm taped on "Back" button in Chrome emulation mode or mobile safari - everything is ok, delay is absent. But when application is running on device I noticed some delay before animation for transition starts. (Duration of delay in default application ~200-400 ms and  duration of this delay  increases proportionally number of HTMLElements in own application)
 I'm attaching two screenshots of timelines for 'back event' in the application and in the mobile safari on the device. It seems that transition on the device  starts only after longest "touched event" dispatched and it's a problem for responsive application UI. This screenshots and description of behavior for default ionic application( "in CLI: ionic start hello").Could someone help me with this question for responsive? Should I send more information?

Timeline for app
![app_ionic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6593044/3011847/505ecfe0-df31-11e3-8fe7-4b43e5ceaf55.png)

Timeline for mobile safari
![browser_ionic](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/6593044/3011849/5588facc-df31-11e3-900a-adf714639360.png)

items.title: Why a Python cmd on a npm/bower base project
items.body:
On Guide Chapter 4 : testing your app, it's very easy to test in the desktop browser :
'python -m SimpleHTTPServer 8000'

but the project is base on npm and bower, a npm package will be more consistency :
Install
```npm install http-server -g```

Use
```http-server www```

And developers who doesn't have python on their platform will be happier ;)

JS power!

items.title: Note in doc to include ng-cordova.js before cordova.js
items.body:
In .html file, make sure to put `ng-cordova.js` before `cordova.js`

    <script src="lib/ionic/js/ng-cordova.js"></script>
    <script src="cordova.js"></script>

If the other way around, I found out the rubber scrolling effect disappeared in ionic list. Not testing completely yet but I don't know why either.

May as well make that as a note in the **docs**.

items.title: android keyboard height bug fix, density incorrect
items.body:
In testing with galaxy s2, the keyboard height was not being calculated correctly.  I found out the density was being set to an int.  

From here..
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/3166501/getting-the-screen-density-programmatically-in-android

Density can be .75, 1, 1.5, 2, ect. thus it was being rounded to the nearest integer and causing the incorrect keyboard height.

I switched it to be a float
